content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I really appreciate the slight wording modification. I enjoyed this clash. Simple concept with a relatively simple execution in a way that keeps it fun. Approved :]

I stumbled a bit reading the goal out from top down. That may be fully my fault, but I think I know what was throwing me off. 

Reading the stub in JS, the array becomes "inputs" instead of "A". This led to a bit of variable confusion, as I wasn't seeing "A" in the stub after reading "A[i]" in the second sentence.
This may not be the proper way to format it, but my suggestion for this would be to add something along the lines of "Given an array of house locations [[A]], for [[N]] houses" prior to mentioning [[A]][i]. This, or just generally some way of describing what [[A]] is, prior to mentioning it (or at the same time you're mentioning it).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear, simple and original. Why did you exclude the case N=1?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice clash with an original concept. Makes you think, but not too hard that you can't solve it in 5 minutes.

Nice clash idea.

I think you need some more tests/validators though.

A naive solution I had tried at first passed all the tests, but failed Validator 2. So I would have gotten 100% in-clash, then only 75% after I submitted, giving me no chance to debug if it were a real clash.

Input
20 3
0 2 18
Working Out:
distances = [2, 4, 2]
max_distance = 4
min_walk = 16

My issue was that to calculate the 'distances' between points, I was allowing the distance to always be the shortest distance possible, rather than simply taking the clockwise distance, so when I found the distance from 2->18 I said it was 4 (2,1,0,19,18) instead of 16 (2,3,...,17,18). This leads to the wrong answer.

It would be good to add at least one test case that has this issue. Basically you need a gap between two houses that is greater than half the perimeter. That will reproduce this issue and allow clashers to debug it in-clash if their code suffers from this mistake.

Goal
* Paragraph 1: Suggest to emphasise that all the houses are on the perimeter of the pond. (Initially I was very confused and thought the houses are some distances away from the bond.)

* Paragraph 2: Please change "[[A[i]]]" to "[[A]][i]"

Input
* Line 2: Please add a brief description of [[A]].

Constraints
* Please format "A" (twice) and "N" as [[variables]].

* Please change "0 <" to "0 ≤", otherwise some cases violate the third constraint.

Cases
* Validator 2: Please change the case so that it's more similar to Test 2, i.e.
(a) answer ≠ maximum in [[A]] – minimum in [[A]], and
(b) [[A]] does not include any negative numbers (that violates the third constraint).

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement e.g. "write answer".

Thanks.

Thanks, I made the changes.
How do you properly format the variable N in A[N], right now I’m doing A[[[N]]] and it’s taking the outer two brackets
Thanks. I have added a couple more test cases.
Thanks, glad you liked it. The problem is about travelling to all the houses, and N=1 is a weird case where you don't need to "travel", so I decided to exclude it.(even though it is trivial)

Hello,
Since A was formatted as a variable I thought it was clear that it is something you get from input. In the Input section you can see that the array A is on line 2.
Unfortunately I don't think you can change "inputs" to "A" in the stub.
Anyway, no problem, I will add "You are given an array of house locations [[A]]." before describing what the elements represent.

I've just tested it - you may use a "line separator" character to achieve the desired format.

(1) Copy the character (U+2028 /  ) by clicking the line separator example here: https://www.editpad.org/tool/invisible-character

(2) Paste the character both before [[ and after ]] (positions indicated as ^ below):
A[^[[N]]^]

(3) Test in the IDE to make sure you do it correctly.

(4) Save the result!
